page.title: 15Alford's Land and Buildings
page.content: The River Don and its haughlands dominate the area which is of low relief (450-625 ft). The granite and schists bedrock is covered by river alluvium and glacial till. The sandy loams and peaty gley soils are mostly cultivated. Fields are divided by low stone walls or fences, hedges are absent but the bare nature of the landscape is relieved by shelter belts, small conifer plantations and amenity groups of broadleaf trees. The traditional building stone was granite but most recent buildings are harled concrete brick. A feature of modern farm steadings are large concrete and metal Dutch barns and metal silos. Listed buildings include Haughton House, its ice house, cottage and lodge, a 19th century toll house and Alford episcopal church.
